am.pdf pdf false 872982 AAM-PDF YJCAT 115265 115265 S0021-9517(23)00510-9 10.1016/j.jcat.2023.115265 The Author(s) Fig. 1 (a) Simplified schematic presentation of a rapid computational catalyst screening approach to identify potential candidates for experimental screening. (b) Our developed approach for Ni-catalyzed Markovnikov hydroarylation of styrenes based on triphenylphosphine ligand which was optimized by a rapid catalyst screening approach. (c) General scheme for transition-metal catalyzed hydrocarbonation of alkenes. (d) Approaches for Markovnikov hydroarylation of vinylarenes. (S)-iPrBox = 2,2-Bis[(4S)-4,5-dihydro-4-isopropyloxazol-2-yl]propane; (S)-PhBox = (4S,4′S)-2,2′-Cyclopentylidenebis[4,5–dihydro–4–phenyloxazole]; (S)-bis(4-hep)Im = (4S,4′S)-1,1′-Bis[3-(1,1-dimethylethyl)phenyl]-4,4′,5,5′-tetrahydro-4,4′-bis(1-propylbutyl)-2,2′-bi-1H-imidazole. Fig. 2 Catalytic system investigation (ligand screening). (a) Ligand screening identifies triphenylphosphine as the only suitable ligand among the investigated. Reaction conditions for Fig. 2a: Styrene (1, 0.25 mmol), aryl iodide (2, 0.5 mmol, 2 equiv.), nickel catalyst (0.025 mmol, 10 mol%), ligand (0.025 mmol, 10 mol%), Me2PhSiH (1 mmol, 4 equiv.), NaOTMS (1 mmol, 4 equiv.), THF (0.2 mL), 45 °C. aVinylbenzene and 4-iodotoluene were used as substrates; b4-vinyltoluene and 4-iodobenzotrifluoride were used as substrates. cNiCl2, dNi(cod)2, eNi(PPh3)2Cl2, fNi(PCy3)2Cl2, were used as catalyst source without additional ligand; g20 mol% of ligand; h40 mol% of ligand; i5 mol% of catalyst, j2 equiv. of Me2PhSiH and NaOTMS; kno Ni catalyst. Conversion was determined by 1H NMR spectroscopy using 1,3,5-trimethoxybenzene as an internal standard. (b) Testing of structural analogues of triphenylphosphine identified by rapid catalyst screening (vide infra). Reaction conditions for Fig. 2b, comparison of P(o-tol)3, P(m-tol)3, PPh3, P(p-F-C6H4)3, P(p-Cl-C6H4)3, P(m-F-C6H4)3, P(C6F5)3: 4-vinyltoluene (1, 0.5 mmol), 4-iodobenzotrifluoride (2, 1.0 mmol, 2 equiv.), MePh2SiH (1 mmol, 2 equiv.), NaOTMS (1 mmol, 2 equiv.), NiCl2 (0.025 mmol, 5 mol%), ligand (0.05 mmol, 10 mol%), THF (0.4 mL), 45 °C. Conversion was determined by 1H NMR spectroscopy using 1,3,5-trimethoxybenzene as an internal standard. Fig. 3 Substrate scope. Reaction conditions: styrene (1, 0.25 mmol), aryl halide (2, 0.5 mmol), Me2PhSiH (2 or 4 equiv.), NaOTMS (2 or 4 equiv.), THF (0.2 mL), 20 h, 45 °C. X = halide substituent in 2. Conversion of starting styrene 1 determined by qNMR using 1,3,5-trimethoxybenzene as an internal standard; anti-Markovnikov product 4 was formed in addition to Markovnikov product 3 (percent conversion to 4 is given in parentheses). The isolated yield is given for a mixture of 3 and 4, and their ratio is given in parentheses. It is indicated when the reactions were carried out at a temperature other than 45 °C, i.e., at room temperature (RT) or 80 °C. Fig. 4 Experiments to gain mechanistic insight. (a) A (0.1 mmol), styrene (0.1 mmol), NaOTMS (0.4 mmol), Me2PhSiH (0.4 mmol), THF (0.1 mL). (b) A (0.1 mmol), styrene (0.1 mmol), Ni(PPh3)2Cl2 (10 mol%), NaOTMS (0.4 mmol), Me2PhSiH (0.4 mmol), THF (0.1 mL). (a)-(e): deuterated styrene (0.5 mmol), 4-iodobenzotrifluoride (2a, 1.0 mmol), Ni(PPh3)2Cl2 (10 mol%), NaOTMS (1 mmol), silane (1 mmol), THF (0.4 mL). (f) allylbenzene (0.25 mmol), 4-iodobenzotrifluoride (2a, 0.5 mmol), Ni(PPh3)2Cl2 (10 mol%), NaOTMS (1 mmol), Me2PhSiH (1 mmol), THF (0.2 mL). Conversions were determined by 1H NMR spectroscopy using 1,3,5-trimethoxybenzene as an internal standard. Fig. 5 Potential surface for the selectivity-determining step in hydronickelation, as calculated at the M06/6–31*(d) level with a COSMO solvation model. The difference in regioselectivity of allylbenzene and styrene is caused by the different stability of the first-step products (reaction intermediates) and differences in activation barriers for transition states (TS). Graphical abstract Advances in understanding the mechanisms of homogeneous nickel catalysis has led to a remarkable progress in this field. However, the discovery of active catalysts is still largely based on trial and error, and the catalysts are mostly based on chelating (nitrogen) ligands. We report a combined theoretical and experimental study of nickel-catalyzed hydroarylation of vinylarenes, where experimental advances were complemented with a rapid computation catalyst screening. Once the mechanism is known and preliminary experimental data is available, the screening approach can predict other suitable ligands by assessing the electronic structure of the catalyst complex without the computationally intensive determination of the transition states. Using the approach described, we developed the reaction that proceeds under unusually mild conditions and is broadly applicable on a range of vinylarenes and (het)aryl halides, including previously inaccessible chlorides. The reaction was found to be highly dependent on the choice of ligand, with monodentate PPh3 proving optimal. Extensive quantum chemical simulations elucidated the reaction mechanism and identified Ni(PPh3)xClyH as the crucial active species. Keywords Reaction development Nickel catalysis Catalyst screening Mechanism DFT Aryl chlorides Vinylarenes Triphenylphosphine Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Tuning the reaction parameters of a catalytic reaction is usually done to develop the optimal conditions for the desired reaction outcome [1]. However, it can also provide valuable insight into the reaction mechanism. In the field of homogeneous organometallic catalysis, fine-tuning of the metal–ligand system is an established protocol for reaction optimization and often the key to understanding the catalytic process. Recent developments aim to facilitate this process by predicting optimal reaction parameters, especially the catalyst structure, using computational methods [2]. To achieve this, studies that bridge theoretical and experimental analysis are crucial. We aimed to develop a novel nickel-catalyzed homogenous transformation that is supported by computational understanding of the reaction mechanism and allows to extend the scope of useful catalysts through a rapid computational catalyst screening approach (Fig. 1 a). To this end, we considered the hydroarylation of vinylarenes as ideally suited (Fig. 1b), since there are already reports of this type of transformation, providing a starting point for further development (Fig. 1c,d). However, the reaction had been challenging because it relies on the in situ formation of metal hydride species, involves several mechanistic steps and is therefore tedious to analyse computationally. Therefore, finding a simplified method to rapidly engineer this transformation or find an improved catalyst would enable similar design strategies in this dynamic area of catalysis, as well as for systems based on other (transition) metals. Nickel is one of the most important metals in the vibrant field of homogenous non-noble metal catalysis [3]. Due to its low cost, versatility and robustness, nickel-catalyzed functionalization reactions of alkenes have attracted considerable attention in recent years (Fig. 1c) [4]. Among these reactions, nickel-catalyzed hydroarylation of alkenes has been most intensively investigated [5], including the hydroarylation of vinylarenes [6]. Reported examples of the nickel-catalyzed hydroarylation of vinylarenes to form Markovnikov products include their reactions with boronic acids in the presence of P(tBu)3 [6a], a chiral BOX nitrogen chelating ligand [6b], or the reaction of vinylarenes with aryl iodides in the presence of an advanced chiral-bisimidazolium ligand (Fig. 1d) [6c]. These methods evolved as an alternative to the seminal asymmetric hydroarylation of vinylarenes with either boronic acids in the presence of palladium [7], or aryl bromides by a synergistic combination of CuH and Pd catalysis (Fig. 1d) [8], and are proposed to build on the in situ formation of Ni–H species [9]. Recent developments have focused on the stereo-control of the newly formed C(sp3 ) center, which can be achieved with the use of nitrogen chelating ligands [6c,d]. However, despite recent headway in the field of alkyne hydrofunctionalization, the mechanisms of these transformations are not fully understood. Empirically it has been established that catalytic systems generally rely on chelating nitrogen [4b,4c,6c,6d,10], or phosphine [3f] ligands because Ni can assume different oxidation states (i.e., Ni(0), Ni(I), Ni(II), Ni(III), Ni(IV)), allowing the reaction to proceed via a single-electron or two-electron transfer mechanism [3b,4b,4c]. Theoretical calculations show either a step-wise hydrogenation with a direct hydrogen migration from the hydrogen-donor to aldehydes when using Ni(PCy3)2 [11], or concerted hydroarylation of styrenes with Ni(cod)2, MeOH and Ar-B(OH)2 [4d]. By combining theoretical and experimental methods, a protocol for rapid theoretical catalyst screening was developed. Once the reaction mechanism is identified (including the transition states, for one catalyst or ligand) and some experimental data is available, the scope of the catalyst screening can be expanded using our approach without the computation of the transition states with other catalysts. Furthermore, one also does not need a precise energy determination for the calculation of descriptors, which have been transferred from heterogeneous catalysis to homogenous reactions [12]. Such an approach does not confer information on the reaction rates or exact mechanism but does give a rapid indication which ligands can be used. Using this approach, we were able to develop nickel-catalyzed hydroarylation of vinylarenes using a readily available inexpensive catalyst, i.e., NiCl2 as a precatalyst with an added monodentate triphenylphosphine (PPh3) ligand, dimethylphenylsilane and sodium trimethylsilanolate as a hydrogen source and base, respectively (Fig. 1b). On the one hand, the method allows the use of a broad range of aryl halides, i.e., iodides, bromides as well as chlorides, which was not the case for the hitherto developed Ni-system. Moreover, the reaction proceeds under mild reaction conditions, i.e., at room temperature or 45 °C, even with aryl chlorides as substrates, which is unusual for transition metal-catalyzed reactions in general. On the other hand, the catalytic system proved to be highly dependent on the ligands. PPh3 performed best, while most other ligands, including structurally similar analogues and those previously used for a similar type of catalysis, did not yield any products. Using the catalyst screening approach, P(m-tol)3, P(m-F-C6H4)3, P(m-F-C6H4)3, and P(m-F-C6H4)3 were identified as prospective ligands, while their structural analogues P(Me)3 and P(MePh2) were ruled out. The experimental testing confirmed this. The mechanism of the transformation was rationalized by a comprehensive theoretical study, where Ni(PPh3)xClyH was identified as the crucial active species, the stability of various intermediates was elucidated, and the reaction pathway was revealed. The experimentally observed selectivity, which changes when allylbenzenes or styrenes are used, was explained with energetic and kinetic arguments using density functional theory (DFT). 2 Results and discussion 2.1 Experimental screening Preliminary experimental data are needed to develop a rapid theoretical catalyst screening approach (vide infra). Therefore, we began our study with experimental catalyst screening for the selected transformation, i.e., hydroarylation of vinylarenes, as indicated above. Structurally distinct catalysts (ligands) (Fig. 2 a) were studied in preliminary experimental screening. The reagents were chosen to allow in situ hydride formation under mild conditions, i.e., Me2PhSi-H, NaOTMS, and reactive aryl iodides as substrates, in order not to avoid the pitfall of ruling out ligands due to the low reactive substrate. A detailed description of the screening of the catalytic system can be found in the Supplementary information (Supplementary Tables 1-4) [13]. Interestingly, among the ligands initially screened, including those shown to be active in similar transformations, i.e., P(tBu)3 [6a], BOX [6b,7], IPr [5f,i], diMe-Py [5e], CataCXium [5h], only the triphenylphosphine was active for the studied reaction between aryl iodide and vinylarene (Fig. 2a). Intriguingly, the electronic effects of the ligand played the dominant role. For example, the sterically hindered P(o-tol)3 did not lead to any conversion nor did PMePh2, which has a smaller cone angle but a stronger electron donating effect than PPh3 (Fig. 2a). Phosphine ligands are versatile soft donor ligands with a wide range of easily tunable steric and electronic factors, usually involved in two-electron transfer reaction pathways, and are among the most commonly used ligands in transition metal catalysis [14]. They have not yet been used for the hydroarylation of vinylarenes with aryl halides as substrates. A wide range of accessible phosphine ligands with different electronic and steric properties also makes these ligands ideal for demonstrating the development of the reaction by rapid catalyst screening, as we show below. To understand these effects in more detail and fine-tune the reaction protocol, further modifications of the triphenylphosphine ligand were studied, paying particular attention to the electronic parameters (Fig. 2b) [15]. Since the conversion using triphenylphosphine with 10 mol% catalyst was almost quantitative (Fig. 2a), we decreased the loading of the Ni precatalyst to 5 mol% for further experiments. Thus, any differences in conversion when changing the ligand substituents would be easily visible. Having discovered triphenylphosphine as an example of a functioning ligand, the computational screening protocol (described in a latter section) identified other ligands as catalytically active: i.e., P(m-tol)3, P(p-4-F-C6H4)3, P(p-Cl-C6H4)3, P(m-F-C6H4)3, and P(C6F5)3 (Fig. 2b). They were experimentally shown to be also active, albeit yielding lower conversions, precisely as predicted computationally. Despite not being calculated in the screening, the identified ligands are adjacent in the Tolman electronic parameter series [15a]. 2.2 Substrate scope By identifying the archetypal triphenylphosphine as a suitable ligand, we aimed to determine the scope of the catalytic systems with respect to various aryl halides and vinylarenes (Fig. 3 ). Fortuitously, aryl chlorides, bromides, and iodides proved to be suitable reaction substrates, whereas previously known similar Ni-catalyzed methods can only use aryl iodides. In order to achieve higher conversions, the reactions for the substrate scope screening were carried out at 45 °C, although the reactions can also proceed at room temperature [13]. The method tolerated both electron-donating (OMe, Me) and electron-withdrawing (COMe, Ph, Ph-C≡C) substituents at the para positions of the vinylarenes. Also 2-vinylpyridine and 2-vinylnaphthalene proved to be suitable substrates. The method was demonstrated on several aryl iodides with different substituents (OMe, Me, Ph, CF3, COMe, COEt) in the para position as well as on aryl bromides with 3-OMe, 3-Me and 4-Ph substituents and on 3-bromoquinoline. Reactions with aryl chlorides, i.e. chlorobenzene, 4-chlorobenzotrifluoride, 4-chlorotoluene, 4-chloroanisole, had to be performed at elevated temperature, at 80 °C, to obtain higher conversions. However, the reaction with 4′-chloroacetophenone was carried out at room temperature to obtain the product with quantitative conversion. It should be noted that transition metal catalyzed reactions with aryl chlorides as substrates are challenging, even with palladium [16], and usually require harsher reaction conditions [17]. The order of reactivity of aryl halides usually follows the enthalpies of dissociation of the corresponding bonds (C-X), i.e., the order of reactivity being Ar-I > Ar-Br > Ar-Cl [18]. The reactions of aryl chlorides we observed (described above) thus proceed under unusually mild conditions and open a new avenue of chemical transformations. During the reaction, in addition to Markovnikov product 3, we also observed the formation of anti-Markovnikov products 4 with conversions of 5–17 % (vide infra for mechanistic explanation). Since products 3 and 4 have similar retention factors on the silica gel and C18 phase – this is especially true for 4 with no heteroatoms or other polar functional groups – a complete separation was possible in most cases only by semi-preparative reverse phase HPLC. Fig. 3 shows the reported conversion as the sum of 3 and 4, as well as the isolated yield. In the Supplementary information, the NMR spectra of the purified products 3 after reverse phase HPLC separation are given [13]. Excessive amounts of aryl halides (2 equiv.) were utilized due to their propensity to undergo dehalogenation under reductive conditions in the presence of a nickel catalyst, such as NiCl2 [19]. The reaction between 2-vinylpyridine and 4′-iodoacetophenone to form 3r was carried out on a scale of 1 mmol. Analysis of the by-products formed in the reaction by chromatographic separation led to the isolation, along with 3r and 4r, of PhMe2Si-O-SiMe3 and acetophenone. The former is formed as side product from Me2PhSi-H and NaOTMS during formation of Ni hydride species (vide infra), while acetophenone is a side product from the reductive dehalogenation (Supplementary Figs. 1-7). 2.3 Experimental insight into the reaction mechanism Intrigued by the reaction developed, especially with respect to the unusual reactivity of aryl chlorides, we have attempted to explore its mechanism. To determine the pathway of nickel during catalysis, we experimentally studied the reaction of oxidative addition nickel complex A with styrene under standard reaction conditions in the presence and absence of Ni(PPh3)Cl2 (Fig. 4 a,b). The formation of an oxidative addition complex of aryl halide with nickel does not occur during catalysis, as neither 3 nor 4 were formed, also ruling out the Ni-Ni transmetallation pathway. Deuterium labelling experiments with styrene-α-d1 , styrene-β-d2 , and Me2PhSi-D showed no deuterium scrabbling during the reaction (Fig. 4c-e). The deuterated products 3 and 4 were obtained in clean forms, indicating that no equilibrium processes take place during the reaction (this was also confirmed by the exothermic profiles of the elementary reactions as revealed by the computational analysis, vide infra) (Supplementary Fig. 10–18). The reaction with the deuterated silane source, i.e., Me2PhSi-D, proceeded much more slowly (Supplementary Fig. 19), which is consistent with the theoretical study (vide infra) identifying the transfer of hydrogen to nickel as the rate-determining step of the process. Thus, the preliminary kinetic study showed a primary kinetic isotope effect (k H/k D = 1.9) for the reaction studied [13]. Importantly, the regioselectivity with allylbenzene with 2a was opposite from that of styrene, yielding predominantly the anti-Markovnikov product (Fig. 4f), which is similar to the reactions without the ligand in Ni-heterogeneous catalysis using stronger reducing agents, e.g., PHMS (Supplementary Figs. 20,21) [5c]. The regioselectivity of insertion had been previously found to depend on how the C=C bond is polarized. Electron-withdrawing groups favor a 2,1-insertion into branched Ni-alkyl species, while the normal alkene groups favor a 1,2-insertion into linear Ni-alkyl species [20]. This difference can be understood by investigating one reaction step computationally, where we observe that the difference in regioselectivity between allylbenzene and vinylbenzene (styrene) is caused by thermodynamic and kinetic effects simultaneously. In the regioselectivity-determining step, hydrogen is transferred from the nickel catalyst to styrene (vinylbenzene) or allylbenzene, yielding a strongly bound intermediate to the catalyst. We observe that in the case of vinylbenzene, the [NiCl(PPh3)(PhCHCH3)1] intermediate is 8 kcal mol−1 more stable than [NiCl(PPh3)(PhCH2 CH2)1]. This thermodynamic effect is furthered by the kinetic effect, as the kinetic barrier for the formation of the Markovnikov product is 8 kcal mol−1, compared to 11 kcal mol−1 for the anti-Markovnikov product. When allylbenzene is studied, the stability is reversed and [NiCl(PPh3)(PhCH2CH2 CH2)1] is 9 kcal mol−1 more stable than [NiCl(PPh3)(PhCH2 CHCH3)]. Similarly, the barriers for their formation are 10 kcal mol−1 and 13 kcal mol−1, respectively. It should be noted that although these barriers are low and do not determine the overall reaction rate, they do influence selectivity. The structures and potential energy diagrams are shown in Fig. 5. In this example, a computational approach is used to understand a specific property of the catalytic system – the (anti)-Markovnikov selectivity – without investigating the entire catalytic cycle, which is presented in the next section. While this approach does not allow for fast screening of suitable catalysts, it can reliably predict selectivity for a wide range of substrates as each requires an evaluation of merely two transition states. 2.4 Theoretical insight into the reaction mechanism We further investigated the reaction mechanism with a theoretical approach to obtain information on the rate-determining steps and construct a fast screening model. Based on experimental observations (see Fig. 4) and literature data, plausible mechanisms were postulated and evaluated computationally (see discussion on concerted or sequential steps (ii) and (iii) below, and the exact mechanism of step (iv)). Each postulated step was investigated theoretically, winnowing out the probable mechanistic pathway as described below. We denote individual species and stable intermediates as numbered structures (e.g. 10 and 11) and the transition states for the conversion between them (e.g. TS10/11). Analogous structures that differ by the number of substituents only are lumped together and distinguished by suffixes (e.g. 10a and 10b). A full list can be found in Supplementary Table 5, and the most probable pathway is summarized later in Fig. 7. DFT studies were performed at the M06/6–31*(d) level with a COSMO solvation model (see Supplementary information for more information), which offers a good compromise between the chemical accuracy and computational cost [21]. While other theoretical studies have started with Ni(0) as the active form of the catalyst [6d,11], we investigate its formation from the stable and inactive precursor. The precatalyst is introduced in the reaction mixture as stable NiCl2(PPh3)2 (10), meaning that formally Ni(II) will be involved in the complexes formed. However, a simple arrow-pushing formalism of oxidation states is less useful for organometallic complexes, and we devote a separate section (vide infra) to their electronic structure, where the versatility of nickel is acknowledged (Section 2.6.). In this section, we investigate the mechanism theoretically. We study five steps of hydroarylation: (i) initial ligand substitutions on NiCl2(PPh3)2 (10), (ii) hydride transfer from dimethylphenylsilane to Ni with the help of trimethylsilanolate as a base (forming an active catalyst), (iii) hydrogenation of the substrate (4-vinyltoluene) in a regioselective step, (iv) C-I cleavage of the aryl halide (4-iodobenzotrifluoride), and (v) C–C coupling of olefin (4-vinyltoluene) and aryl(trifluoridebenzyl). Between individual steps, ligand substitution is also possible or required. Steps (ii) and (iii) might occur in a concerted fashion, as reported in the literature. [6d,11,22], Step (iv) might follow an oxidative addition or halide abstraction pathway [23]. Step i. In addition to NiCl2(PPh3)2, alkene (4-vinyltoluene, 1a), 4-iodobenzotrifluoride (2a), NaOTMS (sodium trimethylsilanolate), and (CH3)2PhSiH (silane) are present in the starting solution. Its ligands can be substituted with other soluble species in simple non-activated reaction steps. Calculating all the possibilities (Fig. 6 and Supplementary Table 6), we find that it is energetically most favorable to substitute PPh3 or Cl– with trimethylsilanolate (OTMS1–), leading to [NiCl2(PPh3)1OTMS]1– (11b) or [NiCl1(PPh3)2OTMS]0 (11a) in an exothermic step (ΔE = –35 and –33 kcal mol−1). It is also possible that two [NiCl2(PPh3)1OTMS]1– (11b) species exchange chloride ions and triphenylphosphine groups to form [NiCl3OTMS]2– (11c) and [NiCl1(PPh3)2OTMS]0 (11a) in a slightly endothermic reaction (ΔE = +7 kcal/mol). Thus, it is possible that the initial solution contains all three precatalyst species. Step ii. The inactive catalyst complexes (11) are then activated by hydride transfer from dimethylphenylsilane facilitated by trimethylsilanolate, which can follow the step-wise or concerted hydronickelation pathway. In this paragraph, we focus on the former, where the [NiCl x (PPh3)3- x OTMS]1– x (11) species react with (CH3)2PhSiH, abstracting the hydride and ejecting Ph(CH3)2Si-O-Si(CH3)3 (which stays coordinated to the metal atom). The ensuing [NiCl x (PPh3)3- x H]1– x (x = 1–2; 12a-b) is the reactive catalyst species, whose formation is kinetically and thermodynamically accessible due to low barriers (E A = 27–28 kcal mol−1) and favorable (negative) free energy for the formation of 12a (Supplementary Table 7). Furthermore, they are again able to exchange chloride and triphenylphosphine ligands: 2[NiCl2(PPh3)1H]1– → [NiCl1(PPh3)2H] 0 + [NiCl3H]2– (ΔE =+12 kcal mol−1). Step iii. Let us now analyze the hydrogenation part of the reaction, starting with 12. Initially, the triphenylphosphine group or a chloride ion of 12 is substituted with the alkene substrate 1a in a slightly endothermic non-activated step (Supplementary Table 8). This gives the possibilities leading to [NiCl x–1 (PPh3) 3-x H(Alkene)]2–x (x = 1–3; 13a-c). The energy changes for these substitutions are 10–17 kcal mol−1. Based on the energetics of Step ii (where 12a was formed), the formation of 13b is anticipated here (+14 kcal mol−1). The next activated step involves the transfer of hydrogen from the metal center to the substrate (styrene, 1a), which can attach to the Markovnikov site, yielding [NiCl x-1 (PPh3) 3-x (PhCHCH3)]2- x (x = 1–2; 14a-b), or the anti-Markovnikov site, yielding [NiCl x -1(PPh3)3 -x (PhCH2 CH2)]2- x (x = 1–2; 15a-b). Although this step is not rate-determining for the overall hydronickelation (E A < 12 kcal mol−1), it does determine the selectivity, as discussed in the previous sections and shown in Fig. 5. Concerted steps ii and iii. Computationally studying a different nickel-catalyzed hydroarylation reaction using Ni(cod)2, P(t-Bu)3 and MeOH, Cheng and Dan concluded that the concerted mechanism is predominant [6d]. They calculated that the hydride is incorporated directly from MeOH into the olefin in one step, with both bound to the metal center. To confirm or rule out this pathway in our system, we analysed this mechanism on our system with two initial reaction complexes. In the first scenario, all species involved are bound to the metal center [Ni((CH3)2PhSiH)(PPh3)(alkene)OTMS]1+ (16), and in the second scenario, a chloride ion is bound to nickel, while silane forms a weakly bound adduct [NiCl(PPh3)(alkene)OTMS] + (CH3)2PhSiH (17). Thus, four transition states are identified as both 16 and 17 could form the Markovnikov [Ni(Ph(CH3)2SiOTMS)(PPh3)(PhCHCH3)]1+ (18) and [NiCl(Ph(CH3)2SiOTMS)(PPh3)(PhCHCH3)]0 (19) or anti-Markovnikov intermediates [Ni(Ph(CH3)2SiOTMS)(PPh3)(PhCH2 CH2)]1+ (20) and [NiCl(Ph(CH3)2SiOTMS)(PPh3)(PhCH2 CH2)]0 (21). However, the barriers for all four steps are larger (E A = 29–45 kcal mol−1) than for Steps ii and iii occurring sequentially. Therefore, although the concerted mechanism is thermodynamically possible and complying with the experimentally observed selectivity (the energy change for the formation of 18 and 19 is more negative than for the formation of 20 and 21), it is ruled out on account of kinetics (Supplementary Table 10). Step iv. The C-I bond in 4-iodobenzotrifluoride is notoriously weak and its cleavage is often cursorily dismissed as a fast, almost non-activated step, which does not influence the reaction rate [17]. Although this is largely true, the reaction step is fast but still activated. In the Markovnikov intermediates [NiCl x–1 (PPh3) 3–x (PhCHCH3)1] 2–x (14a-b), Cl– or excess PPh3 is substituted for 4-iodobenzotrifluoride (2a). The activation barrier for the C-I cleavage in the [Ni(PPh3)(PhCHCH3)(PhICF3)]1+ complex, yielding [Ni(PPh3)(PhCHCH3)(PhCF3)I]1+, is 14 kcal mol−1 and the step is slightly endothermic (+5.8 kcal mol−1). However, the iodine anion is very weakly bound to the nickel center and quickly exchanges for chloride in an exothermic substitution (ΔE = –10 kcal mol−1), yielding 22a and making step (iv) overall exothermic. Step v. Finally, the ensuing [NiCl x –1(PPh3)(PhCHCH3)(PhCF3)]3– x (x = 1–2; 22a-b) undergoes reductive elimination in a non-rate determining step, forming the final product bound in the complex as [NiCl x –1 (PPh3)3– x (PhCH(PhCF3)CH3)]3– x (x = 1–2; 23a-b). This reaction step has a moderate barrier of 20–23 kcal mol−1 and is energetically favorable (Supplementary Table 11). The overall mechanism is shown in Fig. 7 but there are some details that deserve further attention and are addressed in the next section. 2.5 Oxidation addition or halide abstraction in C-Cl and C-I cleavage It is known that C-Cl bonds are approximately 20–25 kcal mol−1 stronger than C-I bonds, making aryl chlorides much less suitable substrates. However, we have shown experimentally that the reaction with 4-chlorobenzotrifluoride proceeds moderately at 45 °C and with good conversion (65 %) at an elevated temperature (80 °C) (Fig. 3). As indicated earlier, transition-metal catalyzed transformations using aryl chlorides as substrates are generally difficult and scarce, and this is even more true for homogeneous nickel catalysis [3a,3d,3f,4b,17]. Studying this phenomenon computationally, we first distinguish three possible mechanisms of the C-X bond cleavage at the active nickel complex: a concerted three-centre mechanism (oxidative addition), a two-centre mechanism with X binding to Ni (halide abstraction) and a two-centre mechanism with Ar binding to Ni (aryl abstraction) [22]. In our case we have: oxidative addition (24 → 25) [Ni(PPh3)(PhCHCH3)(ArX)]1+ → Ni(PPh3)(PhCHCH3)ArX]1+ halide abstraction (26 → 27) [NiCl(PPh3)(PhCHCH3)(ArX)] → [NiCl(PPh3)(PhCHCH3)X] + Ar∙ aryl abstraction (26 → 28) [NiCl(PPh3)(PhCHCH3)(ArX)] → [NiCl(PPh3)(PhCHCH3)Ar] + X∙ While all reactions are endothermic, the concerted mechanism is thermodynamically most favourable (ΔE = 6.5 and 11.8 kcal mol−1 for X = I and Cl, respectively). Kinetically, the activation barrier for 4-iodobenzotrifluoride is 14 kcal mol−1, while for 4-chlorobenzotrifluoride it is 22 kcal mol−1. This explains why the former reacts at room temperature and the latter requires elevated temperatures. As already explained, the overall step is exothermic in the case of Ar-I when including the subsequent substitution of I– with Cl–. The two-centre mechanisms have higher barriers and reaction free energies, making them unlikely (Table 1 and Fig. 8 ). Instead, the reaction follows the classical Kochi mechanism [24]. 2.6 Electronic structure of nickel In organometallic homogeneous catalysis, chelating nitrogen [4b,4c,6d,10] or phosphine [3f] ligands are used with Ni, which can assume different oxidation states (i.e. Ni(0), Ni(I), Ni(II), Ni(III), Ni(IV)), and allowing the reaction to proceed via a single-electron or two-electron transfer mechanism [3e,4b,4c]. Although a useful construct, oxidation states are at best a tool for describing the charge in the ionic-bond limit and predicting reactivity. Computational techniques provide more detail. In particular, we are interested in structures NiCl2(PPh3)2 (10) and NiCl(PPh3)2H (12a), which correspond to the inactive precatalyst and the reduced catalyst, respectively. Formally, this encompasses a reduction of Ni(II) to Ni(0). However, in reality this is a much finer transformation. We looked at the intermediates along the reaction pathway and computed the NBO charges on nickel at a higher level of theory (M06/6-311G+(d,p)). In 10 the charge is +1.17 and in 12a the charge drops to + 1.03 and does not change during the hydrogen transfer to NiCl(PPh3)(PhCHCH3) (14b). In 23b, when the reaction cycle is complete, the Ni charge is again +1.18. A physically more meaningful description follows from the analysis of natural atomic orbital occupancies. In 10, the electronic configuration of Ni is best approximated as [Ar] 4s0.41 3d8.41. In 12a, this changes to as [Ar] 4s0.48 3d8.47. Lastly, we analyse the polarity of the relevant bonds. In 10, the Ni-P bond, there is 20.9 % of electron localization on Ni and 79.1 % on P in a typical polar Ni-P bond. In 12a, the Ni-H bond is polarised with 38.4 % electron localization on Ni and 61.6 % on H. Further insight in the activation of the complex 12a is gives the visualization of the highest occupied molecular orbital (HOMO), which encompasses primarily H and Ni (Fig. 9 ). 2.7 Rapid theoretical catalyst screening During initial catalytic testing, PPh3 stood out as the only catalyst with a useful conversion, while even closely related PMePh2 or P(o-tol)3 failed. While P(o-tol)3 might be ruled out phenomenologically on account of steric hindrance, this is not the case for PMePh2. Only P(m-tol)3 also showed some activity. A robust quantitative measure to computationally characterize other ligands is required, preferably allowing for an a priori classification of new prospective candidates. We note that the ligand must have just the right electronic properties (goldilocks zone) to sufficiently activate the NiCl2X complex. To probe other ligands computationally, calculating transition states is unwieldy due to the number of required computational steps and limited by the inherent accuracy of DFT. As a faster approach, we perform NEDA (natural energy decomposition analysis) calculations and NBO (natural bond order) analysis. In Fig. 10, we show the relationship between the NBO charge on Ni, and the electrical interaction and repulsion between the ligand(s) and the NiCl2 fragment. Both, PPh3 and P(m-tol)3 have a charge of +1.255 on Ni and a similar electrostatic interaction with the NiCl2 fragment. Other ligands exhibited a too weak or strong electron donor effect, pushing the charge on Ni all the way to +1.32 or +1.21. This effect alone, however, is insufficient. In Fig. 10, we also show the core repulsion (XC + DEF-SE) and the electrical interaction (ES + POL + SE) between the NiCl2 fragment and the ligands in the NiCl2X complexes. We see clearly that the active catalysts occupy a very narrow goldilocks zone (note that the values dependent strongly on the exact level of theory, including the functional, basis set, and corrections used). For further fine-tuning of the catalytic system, other ligands were first evaluated computationally. It was observed that P(m-F-C6H4)3, P(p-F-C6H4)3 and P(p-Cl-C6H4)3 fell in the same goldilocks zone. As discussed earlier, experimental tests confirmed that they are also similarly active as P(m-tol)3, showing excellent agreement with computational predictions. This approach eschews calculating transition states or resorting to descriptors [12] but requires an a priori knowledge of the reaction mechanism and some preliminary experimental data on active and inactive catalysts. 3 Conclusion Since the development of nickel catalysis is challenging and usually relies on lengthy experimental testing, approaches that would simplify the reaction development process are being sought. Here, we report a rapid computational catalyst screening approach for the development of a complex nickel-catalyzed transformation. Based on preliminary experimental data and a priori determination of the mechanism, the approach identified other monodentate phosphine ligands as suitable for the reaction. In general, catalytic systems based on nickel and monodentate phosphine ligands are scarce and their mechanisms are still being explored. Here we report a triphenylphosphine-based catalytic system for the hydroarylation of vinylarenes with aryl halides under mild reaction conditions and using readily available reagents. Rapid computational screening built upon an identified triphenylphosphine ligand, particularly in terms of electronic properties, and identified other active ligands. Experimentally, the reaction protocol works even with aryl chlorides, which had previously not been demonstrated. For example, the reaction with 4'-chloroacethophenone proceeded quantitatively to the product at room temperature. Current similar nickel-catalyzed hydrofunctionalization reactions use aryl iodides as substrates, and it is noteworthy that organometallic catalysis using aryl chlorides as substrates is generally challenging. The theoretical investigation of the mechanism using DFT identified [Ni(PPh3)(Cl)(H)] as the active catalyst species, which further reacts with styrene with Markovnikov selectivity. The organometallic nickel intermediate formed is highly reactive as it can oxidatively add to aryl chlorides under mild reaction conditions. These results agreed well with the experimental observations. In the catalytic cycle, four activated steps (with transition states) were identified: activation of the pre-catalyst (hydride transfer from the silane to Ni), selectivity-determining hydrogenation of the olefin double bond, C-X bond cleavage, and the C–C coupling. The former is the rate determining step with a barrier of 27.0 kcal mol−1, forming NiCl(PPh3)2H. The second step, although fast, kinetically and thermodynamically determines whether the Markovnikov (in case of styrenes) or anti-Markovnikov (in case of allylbenzenes) product will form. The aryl C(sp2 )–I bond cleavage is, expectedly, fast. On the other hand, even the cleavage of the aryl C(sp2 )–Cl bond is accessible at elevated temperatures. We have also shown that the charge on Ni changes during the reaction, which is in organic chemistry commonly described as its ability to assume Ni(0), Ni(I) or Ni(II) oxidation states. This is a useful approximation but a detailed computational analyses showed that Ni has a charge of +1.18 in the pre-catalyst form and +1.03 after activation and throughout the reaction. This is supplemented by the visualization of the highest occupied molecular orbital, which corresponds to the Ni-H bond in the active catalyst, while in the pre-catalyst, HOMO does not cover the Ni-Cl bonds. Lastly, computational catalyst screening remains the elusive holy grail of modern catalysis, promising to make the search for better catalysts faster, cheaper, easier and more environmentally friendly. While elucidating the entire pathway of multistep reactions is possible, as we have shown on Ni(PPh3)2Cl2, it is a formidable and time-consuming task. Thus, a faster screening protocol is desired. A possible approach is to use scaling relationships and volcano plots, which had been originally developed for heterogeneous catalysis but can be extended to homogeneous catalysis [12]. They require a fairly accurate determination of the energetics of reactants, products and some transition states, which is limited by the accuracy of DFT methods and geometry optimization thresholds. Although normally not a problem, our reaction is extremely sensitive even to small variations in the ligand used. Hence, a more precise approach is required. Computing the aforementioned electrostatic properties is orders of magnitudes faster than performing transition-state search or even computing thermodynamic descriptors. Requiring only one geometry optimization, this approach allows us to quickly expand the search for suitable catalysts provided some preliminary experimental and mechanistic data is available. While the method is not wholly predictive and it still requires an a priori knowledge of a few active and inactive catalysts, this does not represent an impediment as experimental input is always required. The method is thus used in conjunction with experimental efforts to markedly increase the screening throughput. Note that in addition to being reaction-dependent, the values are functional- and basis set-dependent and should only be compared for production results with identical parameters on re-optimized structures. 4 Experimental section 4.1 General procedure for the hydroarylation of styrenes with aryl halides In a nitrogen-filled glove box reagents were added to a screw-cap glass tube in the following order: Bis(triphenylphosphine)nickel(II) dichloride (Ni(PPh3)2Cl2, 16.4 mg, 0.025 mmol, 10 mol%), stir bar, THF (0.2 mL), dimethylphenylsilane (Me2PhSiH, 2 or 4 equiv.), styrene (0.25 mmol, 1 equiv.), aryl halide (0.5 mmol, 2 equiv.), and sodium trimethylsilanolate (NaOTMS, 2 or 4 equiv.). After the addition of sodium trimethylsilanolate, the glass tube was tightly closed with the screw cap and removed from the glove box. The reaction was stirred in an oil bath at 45 °C for 20 h. The reaction tube was opened, the reaction mixture was diluted with dichloromethane and filtered through a silica gel pad (about 1 cm). Then the defined amount of an internal standard (1,3,5-trimethoxybenzene, TMB) was added into the filtrate. An aliquot was taken and the solvents were removed using a rotary evaporator. The aliquot was analysed by 1H NMR spectroscopy to determine the conversion to product. The aliquot was returned to the crude product, which was purified by column chromatography. Details on theoretical part, computational analysis (DFT calculations) are provided in Supplementary Information. coredata.dc:description: Advances in understanding the mechanisms of homogeneous nickel catalysis has led to a remarkable progress in this field. However, the discovery of active catalysts is still largely based on trial and error, and the catalysts are mostly based on chelating (nitrogen) ligands. We report a combined theoretical and experimental study of nickel-catalyzed hydroarylation of vinylarenes, where experimental advances were complemented with a rapid computation catalyst screening. Once the mechanism is known and preliminary experimental data is available, the screening approach can predict other suitable ligands by assessing the electronic structure of the catalyst complex without the computationally intensive determination of the transition states. Using the approach described, we developed the reaction that proceeds under unusually mild conditions and is broadly applicable on a range of vinylarenes and (het)aryl halides, including previously inaccessible chlorides. The reaction was found to be highly dependent on the choice of ligand, with monodentate PPh3 proving optimal. Extensive quantum chemical simulations elucidated the reaction mechanism and identified Ni(PPh3)xClyH as the crucial active species.
